Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Ketamine and Nefopam for Potentiating Opioid Analgesia

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults eligible for opioid analgesia

Intervention.evidence: 100 to receive ketamine 10 mg and 100 to receive nefopam 20 mg

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of ketamine and nefopam in potentiating opioid analgesia

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in opioid requirement over 24 hours

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and outcome assessors were blinded

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis

Result_Outcome.evidence: Both ketamine and nefopam reduced opioid requirements by approximately 40% (mean difference = [value], 95% CI [range]; p = [value])

Harms.evidence: Sedation was observed in the ketamine group, while tachycardia and sweating were noted in the nefopam group
